content.description: <math alttext="A g C N solid is in equilibrium with A g with a positive one charge aqueous plus C N with a negative one charge aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCN(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>CN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: The dissolution of solid <math alttext="A g C N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is represented by the chemical equation above. In pure water, the equilibrium concentration of <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions in a saturated solution is <math alttext="7.7 times 10 to the negative 9 power molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7.7</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. If a small amount of solid <math alttext="N a C N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is added to the saturated <math alttext="A g C N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution, which of the following would be observed?

choices.label: The <math alttext="K sub s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> increases and more <math alttext="A g C N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> dissolves.

The <math alttext="K sub s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> increases and some <math alttext="A g C N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> precipitates.

The molar solubility of <math alttext="A g C N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> becomes smaller than <math alttext="7.7 times 10 to the negative 9 power molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7.7</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and some <math alttext="A g C N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> precipitates.

The molar solubility of <math alttext="A g C N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> becomes larger than <math alttext="7.7 times 10 to the negative 9 power molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7.7</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and more <math alttext="A g C N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> dissolves.

content.answer: The molar solubility of <math alttext="A g C N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> becomes smaller than <math alttext="7.7 times 10 to the negative 9 power molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7.7</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and some <math alttext="A g C N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> precipitates.

skill.text: 2.F: Explain how modifications to an experimental procedure will alter results.
